name: 東亞語言文化比較
comment: 雲和街教學大樓3樓303教室
description:
The aim of this course is to provide a comprehensive overview of the linguistic diversity in East Asia in relation to the cultural and historical specificities that characterize each of the countries under discussion. The course adapts an historical perspective, and will not border on present-day language planning and cultural policy in East Asia. Students interested in these topics, should enroll in the course entitled “多元文化主義與語言教育” 
In this course東亞語言文化比較we will mainly read and study materials (primary and secondary) that are also known as missionary linguistics (傳教語言學). We will cover the regions of Korea, China, Japan, Taiwan and these parts of Southeast-Asia where missionaries compiled dictionaries, glossaries and textbooks in Chinese dialects. Attention will be paid to the introduction of different orthographies, the role of the church in 19th century language standardization initiatives and programs, as well as the present-day legacy of missionary linguistics in East Asia. A brief comparison with topics in missionary linguistics beyond East Asian borders will provide the bigger picture. This course is taught in English.

syllabus:
The aim of this course is to provide a comprehensive overview of the linguistic diversity in East Asia in relation to the cultural and historical specificities that characterize each of the countries under discussion. In the first half, the course load of texts will adapt an historical perspective, while the second half will include present-day language planning and cultural policy in East Asia.

In this course we will mainly read and study materials (primary and secondary) that are also known as missionary linguistics. We will cover the regions of Korea, China, Japan, Taiwan and these parts of Southeast-Asia where missionaries compiled dictionaries, glossaries and textbooks in Chinese dialects. Attention will be paid to the introduction of different orthographies, the role of the church in 19th century language standardization initiatives and programs, as well as the present-day legacy of missionary linguistics in East Asia. A brief comparison with topics in missionary linguistics beyond East Asian borders will provide the bigger picture. This course is taught in English.

This course will introduce a number of topics that cover language and culture in East Asia. The focus will be on the Chinese cultural sphere of influence, the Chinese diaspora in Southeast Asia, but also the legacies of colonialism and imperialism in the region. Reading skills in Asian languages and Indo-European languages are required. If desired, the practical aspect of the course may include a few lectures in digital humanities that introduce databases and tools for computational linguistics.

Week 1   **週**1  **9****月 9****日**   Introduction and handout of the syllabus

This course will introduce a number of topics that cover language and culture in East Asia. The focus will be on the Chinese cultural sphere of influence, the Chinese diaspora in Southeast Asia, but also the legacies of colonialism and imperialism in the region. Reading skills in Asian languages and Indo-European languages are required.

Week 2 **週2**  **9****月 16****日** Assignment: China, Japan, Korea. Students select one country that has a relation with Taiwan (historical, political, economical, religious etc).

Week 3   **週3**  **9****月 23****日** Introduction to the academic literature on missionary linguistics.  **“**The Scope of Missionary Linguistics”: China

Reading and discussion article by Sandra Breitenbach, _Missionary Linguistics in East Asia. The Origins of Religious Language in the Shaping of Christianity_ (Frankfurt-am-Main: Peter Lang, 2008), pp.25-101

Optional: **“**Linguistic Studies by Portuguese Jesuits in Sixteenth and Seventeenth Century Japan”Reading and discussion article by Toru Maruyama, _Missionary Linguistics_, edited by Even Hovdhaugen (ed) (Amsterdam: John Benjamins, 2004), pp. 141-160.

Complementary Readings:

Emi Kishimoto. “The Adaptation of the European Polyglot Dictionary of Calepino in Japan: _Dictionarium Latino Lusitanicum, ac Iaponicum_ (1595)” in _Missionary Linguistics II, Orthography and Phonology_, edited by Otto Zwartjes (Amsterdam: John Benjamins, 2005), pp. 205-224.

Masayuki Toyoshima. “Phonetic Spellings in Historical Context vs Idiolect: The Japanese grammars by Joao Rodriguez Tcuzu and his holograph documents” in _Missionary Linguistics II, Orthography and Phonology_, edited by Otto Zwartjes (Amsterdam: John Benjamins, 2005), pp. 273-280.

Week 4 **週4**  **9****月 30****日** Discussion of materials that take Taiwan as a case study for missionary linguistics 

Heylen, Ann. “Dutch Language Policy and Early Formosan Literacy (1624-1662)” & “Missionary Linguistics on Taiwan. Romanizing Taiwanese: Codification and Standardization of Dictionaries in Southern Min (1837-1923)”, 2001

Complementary Readings:

Henning Kloter. “‘_ay sinco lenguas algo diferentes_’: China’s local vernaculars in early missionary sources” _Missionary Linguistics III, Morphology and Syntax_, edited by Otto Zwartjes, Gregory James and Emilio Ridruejo (Amsterdam: John Benjamins, 2007), pp. 191-210.

Week 5 **週5**  **10****月 7** **日**   Focus on Taiwan in East Asia, with special attention to the Japanese legacy (part 1)

Introducing, Heylen Ann, _Japanese models, Chinese culture,_ with special attention to the bibliographic  references

Week 6 **週6**  **10****月 14** **日**   Focus on Taiwan in East Asia, with special attention to the Japanese legacy in comparative perspective with Korea (part 2)

David J. Silva.“Missionary contributions toward the revaluation of Hangeul in late nineteenth-century Korea,”_International Journal of the Sociology of Language_ 192 (2008), 57-74.  

Week 7 **週7**  **10****月 21** **日**  The relationship of Taiwan with its neighbors equally points to the countries in southeast Asia. This class will introduce the region, with special attention to the Chinese diaspora in Malaysia, the Philippines, Indonesia, Singapore.

Week 8 **週8**  **10****月 28** **日**  Attention will be paid to the meaning of ‘Formosan’, indigenous, aboriginal and Austronesian. Looking southwards also reaches to Oceania: Australia, New Zealand and islands that have ethnicities who speak Austronesian languages. Beyond borders: missionary linguistics in the Pacific

Reading and discussion: “Lancelot Threlkeld and missionary linguistics in Australia to 1850”article by  Hilary M. Carey,  _Missionary Linguistics_, edited by Even Hovdhaugen (ed) (Amsterdam: John Benjamins, 2004), pp. 253-275.

Week 9**週9** **11****月 4****日** Mid-term exam  

Week 10 **週**10 **11****月 11****日**The topic for this class is Language education and Pedagogy of the languages. This class will include a section on Digital Humanities: databases on languages, dictionaries and keyword search (if desired)

Suggested readings:

Georg Bossong.“The Influence of Missionary Descriptions of Far Eastern Languages on Western Linguistic Thought: The case of Christoforo Borri, S.J. and Tommaso Campanella” in _Missionary Linguistics III, Morphology and Syntax_, edited by Otto Zwartjes, Gregory James and Emilio Ridruejo (Amsterdam: John Benjamins, 2007), pp. 123-144.  

David Mikosz. “Eurocentric Views of Universal Languages from 1605-1828, _Itinerario_ 22.2 (1998), pp. 103-115.

Antje Lann Hornscheidt. “Postcolonial continuities in Danish monolingual dictionaries: Towards a critical postcolonial linguistics”in Eric Achimbe ed.

Week 11  **週**11 **11****月 18****日**Articles on sociolinguistics, journals on language planning and book series on language topics pertaining to the languages in East Asia will be discussed.  

Week 12 **週**12 **11****月 25****日** The focus for this class are case studies in sociolinguistics in multicultural/lingual societies. Students present a paper. Introduction: _Handbook of Sociolinguistics_ (pdf uploaded in moodle) and a selection of edited volumes (Berlin: Mouton De Gruyter) that cover topics in sociolinguistics with languages in a postcolonial setting. Articles for reading will be distributed in class, depending on the students’ interests.

Week 13 **週**13  **12****月2****日**Topics for this class are Culture: ethnicities and language. We pay special attention to the cultural encounter between the languages as representatives of ideologies. The relevance of politics may be discussed. Taiwan in and about southeast Asian literature. Comparative to East-Asian literature on the topic. Literature and cultural translation. Taiwanese writers, cinematographers, artists in East and SE-Asia. A discussion of case studies.

Week 14 **週**14  **12****月9****日**The focus is on how language is used in research on ego-documents, diaries, and oral histories. This class can be combined with a lecture on digital humanities introducing personal documents.

Week 15 **週**15  **12****月16****日** The focus is on how language is used in research on popular culture. This class can be combined with a lecture on digital humanities introducing databases that store data on popular culture.

Week 16  **週**16  **12****月23****日**

Assignment: students prepare a presentation that positions language in popular culture or in personal documents. The topic and region can be Taiwan, China, Japan, Korea, SEAsia.  (part 1)  

Week 17 **週**17  **12****月30****日**

Assignment: students prepare a presentation that positions language in popular culture or in personal documents. The topic and region can be Taiwan, China, Japan, Korea, SEAsia.  (part 2)

Week 18  **週**18  **1****月6****日** Exam

Write a paper on your topic of choice demonstrating a literature survey, major journals and databases, bibliography, and discuss one commonality. Can be a digital exercise.
